title: Why I am uninstalling LoL
body: I've played League of legends since beta, bought the physical edition too, and after all these years I'm finally done with this game. I loved the game when it first came out, loved ranked when it released, loved twisted treeline too, even dominion. After all this time I realized something, I wasn't having fun playing this game in any format, not ranked, not normals, not aram, not even the event modes. My friends quit a while ago and I've just been playing solo, and the amount of hate I get in any game mode is staggering and it sucks because while I want to enjoy league I can't. I just either get flamed for my champ picks (out of meta), or my bad plays even when I'm trying to help. I guess after being flamed and harassed so much it kinda just broke any hope I had of enjoying this game in any way. So I guess what I'm saying is league still has a long way to go to be a "good" community, but hopefully it makes it there without me.

I remember when people were very nice in this game, and some games literally every single person would just go to dragon pit and dance. It's not like that anymore. I've been flamed for the stupidest shit like not leashing a WARWICK. I don't really care about flame, personally, because I just think it's funny. But I wish people were as fun and nice as they used to be. It used to be that everyone said GLHF at the start of the game. I haven't seen that in almost two years. It used to be that you could basically play whatever you wanted. Now if you do it, you get reported for trolling. The game is becoming easier as well, like free wards (trinkets), buff/objective timers, stuff like that, to appeal to newer players. But Riot doesn't realize that they're hurting their older players by doing this stuff (not this stuff specifically, but many other things like changing URF). I still enjoy the game, but it makes me really sad that it's not how it used to be.

I disagree about the leashing. It is just a courtesy. My opinion is every jungler should be prepared to not have a leash.

With that said, I usually will always offer a leash to them. Even if they don't need one: Amumu, Kayn, Shaco etc.

Is there any comparable advantage in not leashing at all? If you go there, land a few shots and return to lane in time to still get all your cs, you get everything. If you don't leash you set the jungler back for no reason. It's not a courtesy, it's the most useful way of spending that particular 10-15 secdons. Not leashing is like walking down the street with a buddy on a rainy day with an umbrealla over your own head and one in your backpack while your friend soaks.

Maybe push wave slightly faster/hit 2 first.

At the dame token though, I have seen junglers smite the first champ even with a leash when holding it for the second camp would be more efficient.

I'm not saying it isn't a good strategy, just that it is a courtesy.

You are missing the link between "nice" and dancing in the river.

> If troll picking is trolling, then why does Riot want people to do it? Riot themselves specifically said they want to open the game up to off meta picks, and they've been trying to break the meta in bot lane for years.

I can only guess as to their motivations, so don't take this as the absolute truth, but here are my thoughts: The number one factor is that an implementation would get messy. If they state that troll picking is not punished they don't have to worry about giving a hard definition on which champion is ok in which position, they don't have to worry about fringe cases where a given pick might have been off the stated okay list, but still made sense in light of the composition of the two teams, they don't have to worry about people getting punished, appealing and figuring out who did so because they had a legit case and who did so because they just want the punishment reversed. The second reason is that there is a vocal troll picking and troll enabling subcommunity which would be outraged, and they don't intend to deal with that including a potential mass exodus on their part.

As for Riot's attempts to diversify support, the reason for that is easy enough to guess: most people don't like playing the role. If LoL is a meal they serve, then the support role is the broccoli in it. But if they truly wanted to get rid of the adc-support setup they would have either added an extra lane or made Rift a 4v4 mode. Short of that they don't have many options other than to motivate people to troll by publishing articles saying some champ can be played in a role that it actuality cannot (like when they suggested that Morde might be an ok pick instead of an adc, which luckily didn't catch on or when they published that Brand might be played instead of a support, which sadly did). And simply trying people not to play support is just motivating them to troll, not "opening the game up to off meta picks", whatever that means. The reasons behind the valid picks in each role derive from the game intrinsically and without a radical change in the game itself it is impossible to redefine a role.

First of all, if he consistently picks so badly that he gets negative feedback so much that he decides to quit all together, he wasn't just picking things that were weak on the current patch, he was picking champions whose kits weren't viable in the role he got. That's the difference between okay off-meta and troll picking.

Secondly, you cannot possibly try to defend picking Teemo instead of a support while at the same time saying you _carried_ with it. If you find yourself carrying with a "support" you clearly haven't done your job as one.

Thirdly, this game is fun when you pick normally, gaining some perverse extra satisfaction from screwing with your teammates just marks you as unfit to be part of a team.

Finally, I don't decide what's okay and what's not, I don't have some set of weird personal ideals about what works and what not that I want other people to conform to. Each position has established duties on the team. Not by me, but by the almost a decade's worth of collective experience of the whole community. Whether a champion can play a role without being considered a troll pick depends on whether their kit allows for the effective rendition of the duties of the role. Again, I don't arbitrarily decide which works where, it's based on the math.

> This is a snap judgement based on nothing more than someone saying they liked playing their own way.

There are many ways to play the game within the bounds of team spirit. If somebody's "way" involves consistently stepping outside of that, then yes, they do deserve the negative judgement.

The alternatives are to split the gold and make the adc underpowered and irrelevant or go for an ap/ad itemization on support budget and fall back hard from pretty early on.
